title: Advice needed for a Jungler from a Jungler
body: Okay so, I consider myself as a main Jungler, I am only level 28 atm. Although I am very open with my champion picks, my favourite Junglers to play are Hecarim, Gragas and Nocturne. I am fairly confident in my gameplay but I know there is plenty of room for improvement and learning... so if anyone here is a experienced Jungler with any tips on how I can be at the top of my game and be as effective as possible that would be very appreciated. Thank you <3

replies.body:
-Buy a lot of wards (1-2 each back) and upgrade warding totem as soon as you get to level 9. The information you get from these is very valuable
-Kill the crab thing in river as often as possible
-Try to gank only if there is a high chance of getting a kill or getting an objective (tower/dragon) after
-Dont gank if you or your teammate is at low hp and/or the enemy jungler is likely nearby, otherwise there is a high risk of dying
-Try to farm most of your jungle when it's up unless you have a very good reason not to. Especially important for red/blue buffs and later in the game when you can clear quickly without losing hp
-Have a rough plan for the next couple of minutes so you dont waste time wandering around trying to decide where to be
-Look around the map alot when farming
-Exploit information you get. Use this to counterjungle/get objectives/gank safely/kill the enemy jungler
-Try to carry a pink ward to use for dragon/baron
-Mid-late game always smite the raptors to get the ward clearing buff. Also try to smite enemy wolves if you are ahead or your own if behind and gromp on tanks. The best camps to smite early game are golems, gromp, and red buff

> [{quoted}](name=McRuthless,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=ALRuArLu,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2015-06-04T01:37:07.411+0000)

> -Buy a lot of wards (1-2 each back) and upgrade warding totem as soon as you get to level 9. The information you get from these is very valuable
> -Try to gank only if there is a high chance of getting a kill or getting an objective (tower/dragon) after

> -Try to farm most of your jungle when it's up unless you have a very good reason not to. Especially important for red/blue buffs and later in the game when you can clear quickly without losing hp
> -Have a rough plan for the next couple of minutes so you dont waste time wandering around trying to decide where to be
> -Look around the map alot when farming
> -Exploit information you get. Use this to counterjungle/get objectives/gank safely/kill the enemy jungler
> -Try to carry a pink ward to use for dragon/baron
> -Mid-late game always smite the raptors to get the ward clearing buff. Also try to smite enemy wolves if you are ahead or your own if behind

Smart, although you are neglecting if your laner is having trouble

Thats one more thing i guess, don't try too hard to help someone thats really far behind. Ganking a losing lane is less likely to net a kill and can sometimes even gift the enemy a double if they're already fed. Plus a losing teammate will oftentimes still be losing even after you repeatedly gank for them (especially if the reason they were behind is because they are simply worse than the enemy laner), and its better to instead invest your time into getting the other lanes a big lead so they can make up for the deficit of the guy who is stuggling. Not saying don't help when people are a bit behind and you can actually turn it around, but just assess where your time will be spent best
If they are not doing well and you don't help them they are more likely to fall behind even more which is definitely not a good idea to just let them continue to fall behind.

This is only because they are bad and can't just farm under tower and play safe.

If your behind build defensive cs under tower and don't keep feeding kills, fact is people feeding, is them being bad and not trying to stop feeding more often then it is anyone else's fault (let alone the junglers)

if your 5 deaths in laning, you have fucked up, and if the game is lost, you have no one but yourself to blame.

Think of it this way, are you more likely to win with a 10-0 mid laner vs their 10-0 top laner, or with a 0-0 mid laner vs their 5-0 top laner. Exaggerated but the point is sometimes the best way to counter a fed enemy is by getting someone else on your team equally/more fed, not by trying to make the enemy slightly less fed

> [{quoted}](name=McRuthless,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=ALRuArLu,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2015-06-04T01:37:07.411+0000)

Thank you for the information <3

-I always like to have wards on me or at least a pink out at all times
-I constantly take the scuttle crab (i take it in my first clear for the extra health and vision)
-I try to always be aware of other players and their stats so i can figure out my best course of action in ganks.
-I farm my jungle in all stages of the game, if there is nothing better for me to do, i farm my jungle.
-I do my best to keep an eye on my mini-map taking in the information to make plays or certain movements in favour of me or my team mates.
-I also do my best to always have vison of Drag/Nash and have it locked down (this includes letting my team know the timer for the buffs and when we should make a play for them)
-The raptor smite buff is my best friend xD considering my main is Hecarim and he is a high gank champion. This being said, i generally take Stalkers Blade (Cinderhulk) as Hecarim, so i like to keep a smite in hand for a gank just for that slow. But yes, i do smite my Gromp and Red :)

Thanks Again xD

buying wards is the main chunk of advice you will get from a good player. however, you need to make your wards valuable by utilizing the vision they give. you need to train yourself you glance at your map every few seconds. its no use buying plenty of wards and spending hundreds of gold on wards if you never look at your map. buying/placing wards goes hand in hand with map awareness.
also if you see the enemy jungler in his jungle because of a ward, don't be a hero and try go 1v1 him. rotate to either his opposite side jungle and starve him out, or go set up a counter gank to the lane you think he is going (whichever is closer)
playing jungle well is like chess. it takes strategy which takes time and plenty of practice to perfect.
gl

I know this is me generalizing but with what I'm reading from your comment you think you have already what it takes to make it high in ranked/ league ect ect, but all you are missing is some secret knowledge to push you there.

Tips? I have no idea what you know already or what you want to improve on.

I don't think I have what it takes to make it to a high rank yet. It will be a long time until I even try ranked. I am confident that I know the basics is what I'm trying to express.  I'd just like some tips on how I can use my time efficiently through the Jungle, how I can be most effective for my team, how to continuously put pressure on the enemy Jungler so I can stay ahead etc... things like that. Thanks

> [{quoted}](name=JnrSoldier,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=ALRuArLu,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-06-04T00:53:09.859+0000)
>
> I don't think I have what it takes to make it to a high rank yet. It will be a long time until I even try ranked. I am confident that I know the basics is what I'm trying to express.  I'd just like some tips on how I can use my time efficiently through the Jungle, how I can be most effective for my team, how to continuously put pressure on the enemy Jungler so I can stay ahead etc... things like that. Thanks

Sure, hecurim and nocturne like to start blue (like gragas) but if you want to clear both buffs on your first run then get a Very heavy leash on golems (make sure you ping to back off so dot champs don't accidently kill it) kill red buff, do raptors or wolves if you think you have the hp/mana (this gives time for smite to go off cooldown) and then hit blue buff (also make sure by level 3 you have one point in at least every skill so you can maximise survivability and damage, I know its obvious but some people become illusioned by having a level 2 skill at level 3 as being good)

Also if you start golems, then ward red in case they are looking for a steal ( this gives you time to think on your next move) and when doing your jg route ward river entrances and major buff areas (not in the buffs, near the entrances so you can see if they get surrounding buffs).

Now, a lot of people will try to use you as a crutch when falling behind, THIS IS BAD. You don't want them to do that because a) they don't care if you fall behind and b) it makes you "inactive" in the rest of the map so their jg has free reign to go where ever they please. Make sure you tell them if you cannot help them in a certain situation, (ie just did a rough jg and are low, completed an objective and/or gank and need to b) because while it is important to help your main priority is you, you don't want to fall behind so someone else gets ahed because that only works 1/8th of the time.

To be effective is to be vigilant, know who is getting pushed and who is low.

in a list to break this down:
- who is where
- who is ahead
- did they ward? (ask your teammates for confirmation)
- is it just them alone? do the numbers tilt in your favour?
- what items do they have? (This is actually mega important, a top lane with ryleas could get you killed if you don't pay attention to that)
- how long has jg been gone? (jglers who gank 80% time won't be able to gank again immediately)
- can your teammate follow up if you cannot fight them alone?
- what is on cooldown? (for you, the enemy laner and your laner. This is really hard to determine without practice)
- what is your hp and mana?
- can you actually kill them?

The last one is the most important to consider as it is not as black and white as it sounds, sometimes it is worth scaring them off to give your ally a break or to save/ avenge them if you came too late. However bad judgement will get you killed 9/10 of the time when sizing up your gank opportunity.

One last thing on being effective, don't take cs. Kills are fine, if anyone gives you shit for it just mute them because you have every right to get a kill if you help them out (not if you just rock up and ks) unless you are greedy and try to deny your ally the kill.

Don't bother going around trolling your enemy jg, you will just fall behind. Although whenever they gank, be waiting for them if you cant get to lane fast enough (when they leave fk them up).

GL

Make sure you tell them if you cannot help them in a certain situation, (ie just did a rough jg and are low, completed an objective and/or gank and need to b) because while it is important to help your main priority is you, you don't want to fall behind so someone else gets ahed because that only works 1/8th of the time.

> - who is where

> - did they ward? (ask your teammates for confirmation)

> - what items do they have? (This is actually mega important, a top lane with ryleas could get you killed if you don't pay attention to that)
> - how long has jg been gone? (jglers who gank 80% time won't be able to gank again immediately)
> - can your teammate follow up if you cannot fight them alone?
> - what is on cooldown? (for you, the enemy laner and your laner. This is really hard to determine without practice)
> - what is your hp and mana?
> - can you actually kill them?
> 
> The last one is the most important to consider as it is not as black and white as it sounds, sometimes it is worth scaring them off to give your ally a break or to save/ avenge them if you came too late. However bad judgement will get you killed 9/10 of the time when sizing up your gank opportunity.
> 
> One last thing on being effective, don't take cs. Kills are fine, if anyone gives you shit for it just mute them because you have every right to get a kill if you help them out (not if you just rock up and ks) unless you are greedy and try to deny your ally the kill.
> 
> Don't bother going around trolling your enemy jg, you will just fall behind. Although whenever they gank, be waiting for them if you cant get to lane fast enough (when they leave fk them up).
> 
> GL

Very helpful! Thank you heaps. Some of these tips I have been working on and trying to improve, but some are new too me and I will do my best to incorporate this into my game-play. Again, thank you for taking the time for this comment. A few things though, with Gragas, i have always started at Gromp,  moving from there to Blue, then to Scuttle Crab and finishing on wolves then Recall. With Heca i do the same, except im left with enough HP and Mana to also get my Red, although, i do hesitate to get that Red before i recall because i think it may be more useful to get it on my way out on 3 for a gank. And Nocturne, i am yet to decide whether it is better to start Blue or Red? What is your opinion on that?

I will be definitely trying out this heavy leash on golums in order to get this full clear.

In response too your line about taking CS, i haven't ever really stolen the cs, when i come in and pull a successful gank, i will either get the minions low for our laner, or if my laner is away from lane i just push out the wave and then move on, leaving friendly minions the push on the tower.

> [{quoted}](name=JnrSoldier,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=ALRuArLu,comment-id=0000000000000000,timestamp=2015-06-04T01:42:18.846+0000)
>
> Very helpful! Thank you heaps. Some of these tips I have been working on and trying to improve, but some are new too me and I will do my best to incorporate this into my game-play. Again, thank you for taking the time for this comment. A few things though, with Gragas, i have always started at Gromp,  moving from there to Blue, then to Scuttle Crab and finishing on wolves then Recall. With Heca i do the same, except im left with enough HP and Mana to also get my Red, although, i do hesitate to get that Red before i recall because i think it may be more useful to get it on my way out on 3 for a gank. And Nocturne, i am yet to decide whether it is better to start Blue or Red? What is your opinion on that?
> 
> I will be definitely trying out this heavy leash on golums in order to get this full clear.
> 
> In response too your line about taking CS, i haven't ever really stolen the cs, when i come in and pull a successful gank, i will either get the minions low for our laner, or if my laner is away from lane i just push out the wave and then move on, leaving friendly minions the push on the tower.

For nocturne, (who i'll never claim to be a guru about) I would definitely consider going red first (although it's your gameplan) and getting e as a first skill. The reason I say this is because with the red buff the rest of your jg will get cleared much faster (especially since your passive lets you renekton q) and he isn't skill reliant in jg (like evelyn, nautalis or gragas) meaning mana isn't a big issue for the first 3 camps or so.

Also for a utility ganker such as noc blue is best for ganking as you can run in with q, fear and spellshield at the same time and finally your auto's should finish them if your ally is backing you. Then because you have blue you can then glide back in to your jg with mana to keep on farming (if low you should even consider starting at red then clearing out the rest, enemy red because most likely you will get blue on the way to gank. Also make sure your jg has vision at 2/3 of your camps and you have wards to probe unknown territory)

This seems like quite misinformed advice.

You should always start q on nocturne, and im fairly sure taking w at level 2 for the passive attack speed boost is more effective than e for the first clear (haven't played nocturne in a while so not 100% sure this is still true), especially if you start red buff side and dont have mana regen from blue

Starting red or blue buff side is often determined more by which side of the map you want to be on (bot gives better leash because theres 2 people, but maybe you want to start top to be on the right side of the map for an invade or early gank) rather than the actual buff. You shouldn't get into the habit of always starting gromp on some champs and always golems on others

Red buff is always better for ganking. Red buff has damage and a slow, and blue buff has 10% cdr (which is usually irrelevant because you still only get 1 rotation of spells off anyway) and mana regen which doesn't do anything in a gank.

Also, nocturne definitely isn't a utility jungler, he has only 1 cc ability which is single target and requires you to stay in range for 2 seconds before they even get ccd

> [{quoted}](name=Chicken4dinner,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=ALRuArLu,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-06-04T00:46:26.999+0000)

I'd just like some tips on how I can use my time efficiently through the Jungle, how I can be most effective for my team, how to continuously put pressure on the enemy Jungler so I can stay ahead etc... things like that. Thanks

Here is a dirty little tip .. that like never works but its still fun .. : when you start the loading screen ult tab out and go to match history and look at all the enemy teams history .. find the one that has been on the longest loosing streak and camp their lane .. just for the lols though .. don't do this actually .. unless i works like every time .. then they will get so mad they will either AFK or just rage .. and both those things will bring down the chances of the enemy team winning. This is better done late at night with a friend so you can laugh together and not feel bad when you mess up and accidentally feed like a pizza to a hungry person. :) happy jungling {{summoner:11}}
